dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Alright, so here's something that's really been, uh, baffling a lot of people lately. The S&P 500 just had its best 50-day streak *ever* last week.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Alright, so here's something that's really been, uh, baffling a lot of people lately. The S and P five hundred just had its best fifty-day streak ever last week.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: On Wednesday, the S&P 500 saw its best 50-day streak in its history even as a massive wave of protests in the aftermath of the death of George Floyd continued to unfold across the country and experts looked ahead to a dismal May unemployment rate on the order of 20%.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Yeah, I saw that. And it's like, at the same time, we're seeing these massive protests, right? And, um, experts are talking about a 20% unemployment rate. It's such a disconnect.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Yeah, I saw that. And it's like, at the same time, we're seeing these massive protests, right? And, um, experts are talking about a twenty percent unemployment rate. It's such a disconnect.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: On Wednesday, the S&P 500 saw its best 50-day streak in its history even as a massive wave of protests in the aftermath of the death of George Floyd continued to unfold across the country and experts looked ahead to a dismal May unemployment rate on the order of 20%.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Totally. It really stumps investors, but here's the thing: it's not a new phenomenon.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Totally. It really stumps investors, but here's the thing: it's not a new phenomenon.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: The disconnect between whats taking place on streets across America and the American stock market has stumped many investors but its not a new phenomenon.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Oh, really? [interrupts] So, like, this has happened before?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Oh, really? So, like, this has happened before?

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Absolutely. Think back to 1963, when President Kennedy was assassinated. The S&P, uh, actually added nearly 20% that year.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Absolutely. Think back to nineteen sixty three, when President Kennedy was assassinated. The S and P, uh, actually added nearly twenty percent that year.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: In 1963, when President Kennedy was assassinated, the S&P added nearly 20%.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Wow. That's... that's pretty wild. So even with that kind of national trauma, the market went up?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Wow. That's... that's pretty wild. So even with that kind of national trauma, the market went up?

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Yeah. And it keeps happening. 1967, Vietnam protests â€“ S&P soared over 20%. MLK's assassination in '68, it gained 8%. Even after 9/11, stocks were up over 1% in the following three months.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Yeah. And it keeps happening. nineteen sixty seven, Vietnam protests - S and P soared over twenty percent. M L K's assassination in sixty eight, it gained eight percent. Even after nine over eleven, stocks were up over one percent in the following three months.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: In 1967, the year of the Vietnam protests, the S&P soared more than 20%. In 1968, the year Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. was assassinated, the S&P gained 8%. While stocks ended 2001 down 13%, they ended the three months following the September 11 terror attacks up more than 1%.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: So, what, the market just has no conscience? Like, it just doesn't care about what's happening on the streets?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: So, what, the market just has no conscience? Like, it just doesn't care about what's happening on the streets?

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Well, Jim Cramer actually said this week, "the market has no conscience. Investors are simply trying to make money."
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Well, Jim Cramer actually said this week, the market has no conscience. Investors are simply trying to make money.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: At the end of the day, the market has no conscience. Investors are simply trying to make money, CNBCs Jim Cramer said this week.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Oof. That's, um, a pretty stark way to put it. So, what are they looking at then, if not all the, you know, social upheaval?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Oof. That's, um, a pretty stark way to put it. So, what are they looking at then, if not all the, you know, social upheaval?

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: They're basically ignoring what they call the "three Ps": pandemic, protests, and politics. They're just focused on what they hope is a quicker, better-than-expected economic recovery.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: They're basically ignoring what they call the three Ps: pandemic, protests, and politics. They're just focused on what they hope is a quicker, better-than-expected economic recovery.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Investors are continuing to ignore the three Pspandemic, protests and politicsand are instead focused on what increasingly is being interpreted as a quicker and better than expected recovery in the economy, David Donabedian, chief investment officer at CIBC Private Wealth Management, told the Wall Street Journal.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: But, I mean, there's still major damage, right? Like, unemployment is soaring. Businesses are pessimistic.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: But, I mean, there's still major damage, right? Like, unemployment is soaring. Businesses are pessimistic.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: But even as investors look forward... there are still signs of major damage in the economy overall. That damage has the potential to weigh on earnings and profits for months, if not years, and a soaring unemployment rate will only worsen the situation.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: For sure. The Fed's saying even with reopening, most businesses are still, uh, pretty down on the pace of recovery. And banks are projected to see profits decline through 2025.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: For sure. The Fed's saying even with reopening, most businesses are still, uh, pretty down on the pace of recovery. And banks are projected to see profits decline through twenty twenty five.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: The Federal Reserves most recent report about the state of the economy, for instance, indicated that even though all 50 states are beginning to take their first steps toward reopening, most businesses are still pessimistic about the pace of economic recovery. And last month, the IMF predicted that banks will suffer sharp declines in profits through 2025...

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: So, this current market surge... it's just pricing in a recovery that hasn't actually happened yet?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: So, this current market surge... it's just pricing in a recovery that hasn't actually happened yet?

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Exactly. Experts like Todd Lowenstein say the market tends to be ahead of the actual data. It'll price in a recovery well before the economic bottom.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Exactly. Experts like Todd Lowenstein say the market tends to be ahead of the actual data. It'll price in a recovery well before the economic bottom.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Markets will price in a recovery well before the economic data bottoms, says Todd Lowenstein, chief equity strategist at HighMark Capital Management. The market tends to be ahead of the actual data itself.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Huh. So the worst for the *actual* economy could still be, um, yet to come, even with the S&P doing so well.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Huh. So the worst for the actual economy could still be, um, yet to come, even with the S and P doing so well.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: That means that the worst could be yet to come, even though the S&P seems poised to soar.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: That's the unsettling part, isn't it? It's a really complex picture right now.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: That's the unsettling part, isn't it? It's a really complex picture right now.
